Graphical abstract A detailed investigation of the effect of Zn on the performance of supported Ni-based catalysts for steam reforming of ethanol is presented in this paper. A Ni/Al2O3 and two ZnO/Al2O3 supported Ni catalysts with different Zn/Al ratio were prepared. For the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 (Zn/Al=0.5) catalysts, only metallic Ni particles were identified after reduction. Under ethanol steam reforming conditions, carbon filaments were formed during the reaction, which led to deactivation of the catalyst. It was shown that Zn present in excess (Ni/ZnO-Al2O3) may form an alloy with compositions ranging from Zn-rich tetragonal NiZn and Ni-rich cubic Ni4Zn. The formation of NiZn alloy with different compositions plays a key role in catalyst performance, improving resistance to coke formation and its stability. Keywords Hydrotalcite Ni-Zn alloy Hydrogen production Steam reforming of ethanol Catalyst deactivation Carbon formation 1 Introduction Hydrogen production via the catalytic steam reforming (SR) of ethanol has been extensively studied [1]. Currently the greatest challenge in developing new catalysts for SR of ethanol is improving the stability of the catalyst. Catalyst deactivation has been generally attributed to the deposition of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface, although sintering and oxidation of metallic particles have also been reported [2]. Many recent investigations have focused on applying different strategies to either hinder carbon formation or to react it from the surface during SR of ethanol [2]. This may be achieved by the addition of a second metal that can induce changes in both catalytic and adsorptive properties. This may be due to a number of factors, including (i) the dilution or the coverage of a fraction of the surface of the host metal (i.e., geometric effects). In that case, the size of the ensemble decreases, and this inhibits the formation of carbon [2]; (ii) changes in the electronic structure of the metal via alloying, which influences the intrinsic activity (i.e., electronic effects); (iii) increases in metal reducibility; (iv) inhibition of metal particle sintering; or (v) the prevention of metal oxidation by the feed. In all cases, the addition of a second metal induces changes in selectivity, affecting more severely reactions involving CC bond scission and that may lead to carbon deposition. Bimetallic catalysts have been extensively studied for ethanol conversion reactions. Different bimetallic catalysts were investigated such as Ni-Cu [3–10], Ni-Rh [11,12], Ni-Pt [13,14], Ni-Mo [15], Ni-Zn [16], Ni-Co [17,18], Co-Cu [19], Co-Fe [20,21], Co-noble metal [22,23], Rh-noble metal [24], Pt-Ru [25], Pt-Sn [26], Pd-Zn [27]. Most of these studies reported changes in activity and selectivity as a function of the second metal. CuNiZnAl mixed oxides with various Cu/Ni ratios have been tested for oxidative steam reforming (OSR) of ethanol [8]. The dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde was favored on Cu-rich catalysts. The addition of Ni promoted the reactions involving CC bond scission to H2, CO2, CO and CH4. The changes in product distribution were attributed to an increase in the density of states at the Fermi level in Ni-rich catalysts. Casanovas et al. [27] investigated the effect of alloy formation on the performance of Pd/ZnO for SR and OSR of ethanol. A Pd/SiO2 catalyst was also used for comparison. For the Pd/SiO2 catalyst, ethanol decomposition to H2, CO and CH4 was the main reaction pathway during SR and OSR of ethanol. On the other hand, H2, CO2, CH4, acetaldehyde and dimethylketone were formed over a Pd/ZnO catalyst. These results indicate that ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde followed by steam reforming takes place over ZnO-supported Pd catalyst. The formation of a PdZn alloy, as identified by XRD and HRTEM, promoted the dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde, the first step of the SR of ethanol. Homs et al. [16] studied the performance of 10wt.%Ni/ZnO for the SR of ethanol. H2, CO2 and CH4 were the main products observed. XRD analysis of Ni/ZnO catalyst reduced at 673K revealed the formation of NiZn alloy with different compositions. However, after the SR at 723K, the diffraction lines corresponding to NiZn alloys were no longer detected and only those that were characteristic of metallic Ni were observed. Unfortunately, the authors did not investigate whether carbon deposits were formed during those tests. In fact, there are few studies of the effect of metal addition on carbon formation. Fierro et al. [3] compared the long term stability of Ni/SiO2 and Ni-Cu/SiO2 catalysts for the OSR of ethanol. The monometallic catalyst significantly deactivated during time-on-stream (TOS). The selectivity to H2 decreased whereas the selectivity to acetaldehyde and ethylene (as well as the formation of carbon) increased. The bimetallic catalyst remained quite stable. The authors suggested that the addition of Cu inhibited the formation of Ni carbide, which is considered to be a precursor for the growth of carbon filaments. The addition of Cu to a Ni/SiO2 catalyst significantly decreased the formation of carbon during SR of ethanol [9]. In this case, the authors proposed that the presence of Cu prevented Ni particles from sintering. This eliminated the large ensembles of Ni metal atoms that favor the formation of carbon deposits. The addition of Mo to a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst also decreased the amount of carbon deposited [15]. According to the authors, Mo species prevented the growth of Ni particles, thereby improving catalyst stability. However, no information about alloy formation was provided. The addition of a second metal may also inhibit metal oxidation. To avoid carbon deposition during the SR reaction, one strategy adopted has been the addition of oxygen to the feed as has been employed for OSR and POX. However, this may contribute to the oxidation of the metal particles, which can result in losses in activity as well as changes in selectivity [22]. A Co/SiO2 catalyst deactivated during OSR of ethanol, which was attributed to the oxidation of the surface of the Co particles by oxygen from the feed [22]. The addition of a noble metal (e.g., Rh, Ru) stabilized Co in the reduced state (i.e., the active phase for SR), thus preventing the oxidation of cobalt particles and, in turn, improving catalyst stability. Temperature-programmed XANES experiments of Co/CeO2-Al2O3 and Co-Pt/CeO2-Al2O3 under SR and OSR of ethanol revealed deep oxidation of cobalt particles [28]. However, the fraction of reduced Co was recovered at high temperature only for the bimetallic catalyst. Therefore, regardless of the fact that alloy-based catalysts have been extensively studied for the SR of ethanol, a survey of the literature does not provide experimentally coherent trends about whether or not there should be any correlation between alloy formation and the resistance to carbon deposition for ethanol conversion reactions. That apparent lack of agreement may be connected to issues related to actual alloy formation/stability during ethanol SR conditions, as well as the uniformity of the alloy composition in the active catalyst. Those issues should be better addressed by observing catalyst phase composition dynamics during both activation and reaction via in-situ studies. Thus, the aim of this work was to study the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts for SR of ethanol by in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy experiments, among other more standard characterization techniques. Different supported Ni catalysts were prepared in order to investigate the formation of a NiZn alloy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A solution containing the desired amount of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3.9H2O (Zn:Al=2:1 molar ratio) and another solution containing the precipitating agents (NaOH and Na2CO3) were added slowly and simultaneously into a beaker containing distilled water, while maintaining the pH constant at ∼9 under vigorous stirring at room temperature [29]. Thus, the precipitate was thoroughly washed with distilled water until the pH decreased to the pH of distilled water. The gel was filtered, dried at 373K for 12h and subsequently calcined in air at 1073K for 5h (ZnO-Al2O3). Al2O3 was also prepared for the purpose of comparison following the same procedure as previously described. Another ZnAl sample was synthesized by using a solution containing Al(NO3)3·9H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O with a Zn:Al molar ratio of 1:2. The precipitation was carried out by maintaining the temperature at 323K and the pH constant at 7.5 throughout the addition of a NH4OH (50v/v%) solution. The gel obtained was aged overnight and then washed with distilled water. Finally the gel was dried at 383K and calcined at 1073K in air flow for 8h (ZnAl2O4) [30]. Ni/Al2O3, Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation. The required amounts of metal salt solutions (Ni(NO3)2 6H2O) were used to yield 15wt.% of Ni. The solutions were dried with constant stirring at 373K until the point of dryness, further dried in an oven at 373K for 12h, and then calcined in static air at 723K. 2.2 BET surface area The BET surface areas of the samples were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer by nitrogen adsorption at the boiling temperature of liquid nitrogen. 2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) X-ray powder diffraction pattern of the calcined and reduced/passivated samples were obtained with CuKα radiation (λ=1,5406Å) using a RIGAKU diffractometer. Data were collected over the 2θ range of 20–80° at a scan rate of 0.04°/step and a scan time of 1s/step. For the XRD analysis of reduced catalysts, the calcined samples were reduced under pure hydrogen (30mL/min) at 873 or 1023K for 1h (same reduction conditions used for the catalytic test), purged under N2 at the same temperature for 30min and cooled to 298K. Then, the reactor was maintained at 209K for 1h, using a mixture of isopropyl alcohol and liquid nitrogen and the catalyst was passivated with a mixture of 5% O2 in helium. The Scherrer equation was used to estimate the crystallite mean diameter of metallic Ni and NiZn particles, using the lines at 2θ=51.8 (Ni°) and 51.0 (NiZn). 2.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) experiments were performed using a TA Instruments TGA analyzer (SDT Q 600) in order to quantify the amount of carbon formed over the catalyst. Approximately 10mg of spent catalyst was heated under air flow from room temperature to 1173K at a heating rate of 20K/min and the weight change was measured. 2.5 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) SEM analyses of the fresh and spent catalysts were carried out using a FEI Inspect S scanning electron microscope equipped with a secondary electron analyzer. The microscope was also equipped with an EDAX energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). 2.6 X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) In-situ XAS experiments were performed at the D04B-XAFS − 1 beamline of the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Source (LNLS, Campinas). Typically, a mixture containing 20mg of the sample and 80mg of boron nitride was pressed and the resulting wafers were then placed into a sample holder located inside a quartz tubular reactor and temperature was controlled by a furnace. X-ray absorption near edge spectra (XANES) were measured at either the Ni or Zn K edge (E0 =8.333 keV and 9.659 keV, respectively) during reduction. The sample was heated under a 5% H2/He mixture at 5Kmin−1 up to the final reduction temperatures used in this study (873 or 1023K), and then held for 1h at those temperatures. The H2/He mixture was then replaced by the reactant mixture containing 80% He, 15% H2O, 5% ethanol at the reaction temperatures used in this study (673 or 773K), and held for 1h (i.e., SR conditions). The downstream gas was analyzed by a mass spectrometer model OMNISTAR GSD 320 (Pfeiffer). For the extended X-rays absorption fine structure (EXAFS) experiments, the samples were previously reduced at 1023K under pure H2 and then passivated using the same procedure previously described in XRD section. The pre-treated samples were then activated in-situ activated under a 5% H2/He mixture at 5Kmin−1 up to 773K for 1h, and subsequently exposed to a flow of H2O/Ethanol with a molar ratio of 3:1at that same temperature for 4h. EXAFS spectra were then recorded, successively, in (i) the passivated sample at room temperature, prior to any further in-situ treatment; (ii) after 1h activation at 773K, under dilute H2 flow, (iii) after 4h under a flow of an Ethanol:H2O (He) mixture at 773K and then (iv) after the sample was cooled to room temperature under flowing He. XANES spectra were treated by pre-edge background subtraction using a first order linear function. Following background subtraction, the normalized XANES spectra were then trimmed to a suitable energy range (c.a.100eV above the absorption edge). The Ni-containing phase composition during sample activation and reaction was analyzed by the linear combination method using normalized Ni K-edge XANES spectra (LC-XANES) within the 8.3–8.43 keV energy range. The references used for the fitting procedure were Ni foil and NiO (references for the Ni° and Ni2+states, respectively). Data reduction for EXAFS spectra was made using the WinXAS software [31]. Baseline correction for Ni and Zn K-edges were made by using a Victoreen function in the 8.6–9.0 keV and 9.6–10 keV ranges, respectively. Pre-edge regions were corrected by using a first order function. Edge jumps were calibrated to the first inflection point in the edge of the reference used. The k2χ(k) functions were Fourier transformed (and back-transformed to generate the first coordination shell filtered k2χ(k) functions) within a 1.8–2.8Å Hanning window (unless explicitly stated otherwise). EXAFS k2-space fitting was performed using the FEFF 6 software [32], by considering the amplitudes and phase shifts generated from the scattering patterns through the first coordination shell of theoretical models of NiZn alloys. The Ni edge was modeled by a fcc Ni4Zn alloy (ICSD 647139). The Zn edge was better modeled by considering the presence of both ZnAl2O4 and a tetragonal NiZn alloy (ICSD 105469) phases. These models were chosen as they were detected in the diffractogram of the catalyst after reduction at 1023K, under pure H2, followed by passivation under 5%O2/He mixture as previously described in the XRD section. The Ni4Zn phase was regarded to be a Ni fcc arrangement with six of the eight corners occupied by Zn atoms. The distances were then recalculated from the lattice parameter (a=3.5694Å) obtained from the XRD pattern, being Ni–Ni and Ni-Zn interatomic distances both equal to 2.5237Å (1.4% longer than the actual Ni–Ni bond distances). The NiZn phase is a tetragonal configuration (a=b=2.76Å; c=3.193), with unit cell corners occupied by Ni and its core occupied by a Zn atom. The spectra were represented in R-space by Fourier transformed k2.χ(k) functions within a Hanning window. The first coordination shell fits were compared to the filtered, back transformed spectra. Data fitting allowed the estimation of structural parameters such as Nm, R and σdw, which are the number of neighboring scatterers around the absorber atom, the interatomic bond lengths and the Debye-Waller factor. 2.7 Catalytic tests SR was performed using a fixed-bed quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure. Prior to reaction testing, catalysts were reduced at 1023K for 1h and then purged under N2 at the same temperature for 30min. The reactions were carried out at 773K and a H2O/ethanol molar ratio of 3.0 for all catalysts. Ni/Al2O3, Ni/ZnAl2O4 and Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited high initial ethanol conversion (83, 100 and 99%, respectively). For Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, H2 and CO2 were the main products formed along with CO, CH4 and small amounts of acetaldehyde and ethylene. These products suggest the occurrence of SR of ethanol, ethanol decomposition, ethanol dehydrogenation and ethanol dehydration reactions. Only H2, CO, CO2 and small amounts of CH4 were detected for Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst, indicating that SR of ethanol is the main reaction taking place. Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts significantly deactivated during reaction at 773K. However, ethanol conversion and product distributions remained quite constant during 28h of TOS for the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst. Since the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest stability for SR of ethanol at 773K, this catalyst was studied in greater detail. This catalyst was tested for SR of ethanol under different reaction conditions (reaction temperatures: 673 and 1073K; catalyst reduction temperature: 873K). Fig. 4 shows the ethanol conversion and product distributions as a function of TOS for Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst during SR at 673 and 1073K under H2O/ethanol ratio=3. The catalyst significantly deactivated during reaction at 673K, whereas ethanol conversion remained quite constant during SR at 1073K. Therefore, the stability of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst is significantly affected by the reaction temperature. Increasing the reaction temperature promoted the stability of the catalyst. For the low reaction temperature, H2, CO, and CH4 were the main products formed with small amounts of CO2, and acetaldehyde. This result indicates that ethanol decomposition is the main reaction taking place at this temperature. According to the literature, the main reaction pathway at 673K is ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde, followed by its decomposition to CO and CH4 [35,36]. At high reaction temperature, only H2, CO and CO2 were produced, which suggests that SR of ethanol and the reverse of Boudouard [34] reactions occurs. The ethanol conversion and product distribution as a function of TOS for SR of ethanol at 773K over the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 873K are shown in Fig. 5 . When the catalyst was reduced at lower temperature, significant deactivation was observed. The main products formed were H2, CO2 and CO. The decrease in ethanol conversion was accompanied by an increase in acetaldehyde selectivity. In order to determine the main causes of catalyst deactivation, the used Ni supported catalysts were characterized by SEM and TG analysis and the results obtained are presented in the following section. 3.3 Characterization of post-reaction Ni supported catalysts Fig. 6 shows the SEM images of the Ni-based catalysts after SR of ethanol at different reaction temperatures. A large amount of carbon, in the form of carbon filaments, was observed after SR of ethanol at 773K over Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts (Fig. 6a and b). However, carbon filaments were either not detected on Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst after SR of ethanol at 773K (Fig. 6c) and after reaction at 1073K (Fig. 6e) or detected only to a minor extent in the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst after SR of ethanol at 673K (Fig. 6d). After SR of ethanol at 773K, the TPO profiles (not shown) of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts exhibited peaks at 795, 812 and 851K. For Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst, no peak was observed on the TPO profile after SR at 773 and 1073K, whereas peaks at 777, 820 and 843K were detected after reaction at low temperature (673K). According to the literature [37], the several peaks in the TPO profile indicates the presence of different types of carbon. Then, the peak at 777/795K and 812/820K are attributed to carbon filaments while the peak at high temperature (851/843K) is associated with graphitic carbon. The rate of carbon deposition on all catalysts after different reaction conditions, as determined by TG analysis, is listed in Table 2 . For this calculation, the contribution of nickel reoxidation was removed. After SR of ethanol at 773K, the largest amount of carbon was formed on Ni/ZnAl2O4. However, no carbon deposits were detected on the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 1023K. The literature reports important carbon formation during SR of ethanol over Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts. Augustin et al. [34] observed significant carbon deposition during SR of ethanol at 773K over 30wt.% Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalyst. XRD, Raman and SEM analysis of used catalyst showed the formation of graphitic carbon and carbon filament. In addition, an X-ray diffraction pattern of the spent catalyst revealed the presence of metallic Ni phase, nickel zinc carbide (Ni3ZnC0.7) and graphitic carbon. This result suggests that carbon deposits are formed over metallic Ni particles, producing a carbide phase, which is regarded to be a precursor for carbon filament formation. Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts with different Ni loading (1–25wt.%) and a Zn:Al atomic ratio of 0.6 were tested for the SR of ethanol at 773K [38]. XRD and TG of the used catalyst revealed the presence of carbon deposits. Carbon formation has also been observed during SR of ethanol over Ni-based catalysts derived from NiZnAl hydrotalcite-like precursors [33,39,40]. Zeng et al. [40] carried out the SR of ethanol at 973K over NiZnAl catalyst (15wt.% Ni). TG analysis of the spent catalyst showed that a large amount of carbon was deposited during the reaction. In addition, the diffractogram of the used catalyst exhibited the lines characteristic of graphitic carbon and the metallic Ni phase. Therefore, the results reported in the literature reveals that the formation of carbon during SR of ethanol occurs on the metallic Ni particles and a Ni carbide phase is formed, which is the precursor of carbon filament. In the present work, significant carbon deposition was observed over Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, which exhibited only metallic Ni particles, as revealed by XRD. On the other hand, Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst remained quite stable during SR of ethanol at 773K, which was likely due to the inhibition of carbon formation as revealed by SEM and TG analyses. In addition, the diffractogram of the reduced catalyst showed the presence of NiZn alloy. Therefore, these results indicate that carbon deposits are formed over metallic Ni particles as suggested by the literature. However, the formation of carbon is suppressed during SR of ethanol when the NiZn alloy was formed. The amount of carbon formed on Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst was strongly dependent on the reaction temperature. A large amount of carbon was deposited during the SR at 673K (20.1mgcarbon/gcatal/h). However, the SEM images revealed the presence of only few carbon filaments indicating that this corresponds mainly to amorphous carbon. Increasing the reaction temperature from 673 to 773K resulted in the suppression of carbon accumulation on the catalyst surface. Carbon deposition was no longer observed during SR at 1073K. Wang et al. [41] also studied the effect of the SR reaction temperature on the performance of a Co/CeO2 catalyst. Severe deactivation was observed at 623 and 723K. In this case, the cobalt particles were found to be completely encapsulated by coke. When the reaction was carried out at 773 or 823K, carbon filaments were detected but the catalyst remained quite stable for 8h of TOS. Above 873K, carbon deposits were no longer detected by TEM analysis. According to Augustin et al. [34], carbon is removed from the surface of the catalyst by the reverse of the Boudouard reaction, which improves catalyst stability during SR at high temperature. Therefore, the decrease of carbon formation when the reaction temperature increases observed in our work is in agreement with the literature. The reduction temperature of the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 sample also influenced the amount of carbon deposited. The reduction at 873K led to the formation of carbon on Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst, whereas carbon was not formed after reduction treatment at 1023K. 3.4 - XANES/EXAFS experiments The formation of a NiZn alloy during the reduction seems to play a key role in the catalyst resistance to carbon accumulation. However, the destruction of the NiZn alloy under reaction conditions has been reported in the literature [16] and it could lead to the formation of carbon due to the presence of metallic Ni particles. Homs et al. [16] studied the SR of ethanol over 10wt.%Ni/ZnO. The diffractogram of Ni/ZnO catalyst reduced at 673K revealed the formation of NiZn alloy with different compositions. However, after SR at 723K, the lines corresponding to the NiZn alloys were no longer detected and only the diffraction lines characteristic of metallic Ni were identified. This result suggested that the NiZn alloy was destroyed during the SR of ethanol reaction. Therefore, in situ XAS studies were performed in order to determine the role of the NiZn alloy on catalyst stability. 3.4.1 XANES experiments Fig. 7 shows the Ni K-edge XANES spectra of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst and a reference NiO recorded during a reduction ramp under a mixture of 5% H2 in helium. The spectrum of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst at room temperature is very similar to the spectrum of the NiO reference, indicating that NiO particles were present in this catalyst. Increasing the temperature the intensity of the white line peak decreases as Ni2+ is reduced to Ni°. After the ramp, the temperature was kept constant for 1h, still under H2 flow, and then an ethanol/water vapor mixture was flowed through the sample for 4h. Ni K edge XANES spectra of the Ni/ZnO2-Al2O3 catalyst at different conditions and references (NiO and Ni foil) are shown in Fig. 8 . After reduction at 873K, the spectrum indicates that part of Ni is still in the oxidized form. Increasing the reduction temperature to 1023K showed that Ni is completely reduced (Figs. 8 a and b). When the reaction mixture was admitted into the reaction chamber at 773K, a small fraction of metallic Ni is oxidized regardless the previous reduction temperature of the catalyst (Fig. 8c). On the other hand, significant changes were observed in the catalyst reduced at 1023K and under SR at 673K. The intensity of the white line strongly increased, indicating that a considerable part of Ni is oxidized back to Ni2+, arguably forming a well dispersed NiO phase. After reaction for 4h, the intensity of the white line decreased, showing that nickel oxide was reduced (Fig. 8d). However, a significant fraction of Ni still remained in an oxidized state after SR of ethanol at 673K for 4h. The evolution of the Ni species during reduction and SR of ethanol over Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst at different temperatures is shown on a more quantitative basis by LC XANES (Fig. 8e). The evolution of the reaction products with TOS for SR of ethanol at 673 and 773K over Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst was also followed downstream by mass spectrometry and the data are presented in Fig. 9 . When the reaction feed was injected into the reactor at 773K, the signals corresponding to H2, CO, CO2 and CH4 increased at the beginning of reaction and then leveled off. Only trace amounts of acetaldehyde was observed. The same result was obtained for SR of ethanol at 773K over the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 873K, except that a higher formation of acetaldehyde was observed. These results agrees very well with those obtained for the long-term catalytic tests carried out in the fixed-bed reactor. For the SR of ethanol at 673K, H2, CO and CH4 are the main products formed, indicating that ethanol decomposition reaction is favored at low reaction temperature. However, the concentration of acetaldehyde significantly increased in the first reaction hour when the SR of ethanol was performed at 673K. This was followed by a significant oxidation of the Ni particles when they were exposed to the reaction mixture at 673K, as revealed by XANES analyses. Then, acetaldehyde formation decreased as the Ni2+ containing phase was reduced to metallic Ni during the reaction. The oxidation of metallic particles by water has been reported in the literature [28,42]. Said et al. [42] investigated the oxidation of metallic Co particles by water using in situ XANES. Co/SiO2 catalysts with different Co particle size were exposed to a flow of H2O/He and heated up to 673K. The oxidation of Co/SiO2 catalysts by water was Co-size and temperature dependent. Large Co particles underwent low oxidation whereas the catalyst with medium-sized Co crystallites was significantly oxidized between 373 − 573K. Recently, Avila-Neto et al. [28] used XANES to follow the evolution of Co species when a Co/Al2O3 catalyst was heated under a flow of a mixture containing water and ethanol (H2O/Ethanol=3). Oxidation of metallic Co particles by water was observed at low temperatures and achieved a maximum degree of oxidation at around 573K. Above this temperature, the fraction of metallic Co particles increases, indicating that Co oxide particles are reduced by syngas produced through SR of ethanol at temperatures higher than 623K. The higher rate of dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde over metal oxides has also been reported in the literature [22,43]. de la Pena O’shea investigated the SR of ethanol over Co3O4 by in situ X-ray diffraction coupled to gas chromatography [43].They demonstrated that ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde was the main reaction in the presence of cobalt oxide. When cobalt oxide was reduced, the selectivity to acetaldehyde decreased. Pereira et al. [22] studied the performance of Co/SiO2, CoRh/SiO2 and CoRu/SiO2 for OSR of ethanol. The decrease in ethanol conversion was accompanied by a decrease in hydrogen selectivity and an increase in acetaldehyde selectivity. Catalyst deactivation was attributed to oxidation of the surface of the Co particles by oxygen from the feed. Also, the cobalt oxide formed favored dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. In our work, XANES and mass spectrometry results suggest that the metallic Ni particles are partially oxidized by water in the feed, and these NiO particles promote the dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde at 673K. Therefore, the oxidation of metallic Ni particles might contribute for the deactivation observed for SR of ethanol at 673K (Fig. 4a). At higher reaction temperature (773K), there is only a slight oxidation of metallic Ni particles because the syngas produced through SR of ethanol keep the Ni particles reduced, regardless the reduction temperature of the catalyst. Then, the deactivation observed for the catalyst reduced at 873K (Fig. 5) is not caused by the oxidation of metallic Ni particles. In this case, the loss of activity of this catalyst is likely due to carbon deposition, as demonstrate by TG analyses. 3.4.2 EXAFS experiments While XANES allows information mainly about the oxidation state of the absorbing element in the sample, analysis of the extended part of the spectra (EXAFS) also gives information about the ordering and composition of a few coordination shells around the absorber. EXAFS experiments could then give further evidences for the NiZn alloy formation, which was suggested by XRD experiments of the reduced catalyst and, most interestingly, whether or not such alloys would be stable under the conditions for SR of ethanol. As previously discussed, Ni/ZnAl2O4 and Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited different performance during SR of ethanol. A considerable amount of carbon was deposited over Ni/ZnAl2O4 after 28 h of TOS. In addition, no metallic phase other than Ni fcc was formed after reduction. In the case of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst, the formation of carbon was not found. Furthermore, XRD experiments for Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst presented evidence that the metallic phases most likely present in the reduced catalyst were Ni4Zn fcc (ICSD # 647139) and tetragonal NiZn (ICSD # 105469). Taking into account the presence of these phases identified by XRD, Ni-rich Ni4Zn and the more Ni diluted NiZn phase theoretical models were used for fitting the Ni and Zn K-edge spectra, respectively. From a qualitative comparison of the results, some remarks about the structure of the working catalyst could be drawn. As depicted in Fig. S1a the Ni4Zn unit cell may be represented by a fcc structure whose six faces as well as two out of the eight corners are occupied by Ni atoms. The remaining six corner sites are occupied by Zn atoms. According to that model, the first coordination shell around each Ni atom is composed of 12 Ni atoms at a distance of 2.52 Å (only 1.6% longer than the Ni-Ni distance in fcc Ni, that is 2.48 Å), with the second coordination shell having six Zn atoms. It could be expected then that the FT-transformed EXAFS patterns of this Ni4Zn alloy should be quite comparable to Ni fcc. In fact, the FEFF generated FT-EXAFS spectrum of Ni4Zn (not shown) is very similar to the one of a Ni foil. The only difference being that the peak located at the first coordination shell is in fact shifted to longer distances in Ni4Zn, and these longer atomic distances are considered in this model (2.5237 Å vis à vis Ni fcc’s 2.4890 Å). The other model considered for fitting the Zn edge spectra, NiZn (ICSD # 105469), as depicted in Fig. S1b, is a tetragonal cube with its corners and the core sites being occupied by Ni and Zn atoms, respectively. According to that model, a Zn atom is surrounded by eight Ni atoms at a distance of 2.52 Å (5.3% shorter than the Zn-Zn distance, which is 2.66 Å) and by four Zn atoms at 2.76 Å. The FEFF generated FT-EXAFS of our NiZn theoretical models reveals that the Zn-Ni first coordination shell occurs at a considerably smaller distance than the Zn-Zn found in the Zn foil FT-EXAFS. EXAFS analysis was then performed for the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts. The fitted spectra and the fitting parameters obtained are presented in Figs. 10 and 11 Tables 3 and 4 , respectively. When one compares the experimental spectra of the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst with the Ni foil, the first shell peaks are similar, unlike those found in the Ni4Zn theoretical spectrum. The differences in the Ni–Ni distances in the Ni foil in comparison to the NiZn intermetallic distances of the sample could be due to two factors: (i) a FT-EXAFS peak broadening effect due to the thermal and static fluctuation of the average crystalline interatomic distances (represented by the Debye-Waller term, σDW), expected for measurements at high temperatures (773K) and in small particles [32];(ii) The fact that some Ni fcc was also detected by XRD, probably in the form of very small domains dispersed over the support. However, the most striking difference found between the spectra of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 and Ni foil reference was with regard to the peaks related to coordination shells farther than the first. In that case, the orderly, clear peaks assigned to the 2nd, 3rd and 4th coordination shells found in the FT EXAFS of the Ni foil cannot be reproduced by the Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 spectra, regardless of the in-situ treatment to which the sample was exposed. This suggests that Ni is present in very small domains, being that Zn induces a high degree of disorder in coordination shells farther than the first one and it also has been regarded as an indication of alloying in bimetallic systems [44]. As for the evolution of the distribution of Zn containing phases, it can be observed in the Zn K-edge Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra of the reduced passivated Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 sample that besides the peaks assigned to Zn-O and Zn-O-Me, (Me=Zn or Al), this latter one of quite low intensity, there is a pronounced peak, which is somewhat shifted towards lower distances than the peak related to the first coordination shell of the Zn foil. However it is located at similar first shell distances found in the FEFF generated FT-EXAFS of the NiZn model. By that peak, it appears that, besides it is present in an oxide form (which according to the XRD profiles in Fig. 3, is mainly ZnAl2O4 along with traces of a highly dispersed ZnO phase), Zn is also present in a metallic form. However, its first coordination shell distances are shorter than the ones found in a Zn hcp phase. Therefore, the qualitative analysis of the FT-EXAFS spectra indicates that metallic Zn is present in the reduced sample in a tetragonal NiZn phase, which is richer in Zn than the Ni4Zn model considered for describing the Ni edge spectra. The evolution of both Ni and Zn environments as the sample underwent different treatments may be better observed by considering the average number of first neighbor atoms (N) in the fitting parameters presented in Tables 3 and 4. With regard to the Ni K-edge spectra, inspection of EXAFS parameters of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 (Table 3) reveals that the average number of Ni neighbors of the reduced catalyst (NNi-Ni = 7.8 ± 0.8) only slightly grew (NNi-Ni = 9.0 ± 1.0) after under SR of ethanol reaction for 4 h. As for the coordination number for Ni-Zn (NNi-Zn), it is observed that it also slightly increased from NNi-Zn = 2.4 ± 0.7–2.7 ± 1.5. These results revealed that particle sintering was not important during SR of ethanol at 773 K. From the Zn edge standpoint, Zn-O in tetrahedral ZnO4 units located in a cubic ZnAl2O4 phase was considered in the fitting (see Fig. S1c for a graphic depiction of the cubic ZnAl2O4 unit cell). The subsequent Zn-O-Al scattering paths were not considered in our model due to the fact that it led invariably to very bad fittings with quite large uncertainties in the parameters. That might be ascribed to the fact that the peak corresponding to the Zn-O-Al distances (in the FT-EXAFS spectra) in the samples, compared to the ZnAl2O4 reference, were rather small. It is suggested then that Zn2+ ions are present in the form of isolated ZnOx unities. This usually occurs in catalysts comprised of transition metal oxides highly dispersed on the support, for instance as in SiO2 supported Ti catalysts for partial oxidation of olefins, where TiIVO4 isolate tetrahedral units are highly dispersed over the SiO2 matrix [45]. In that case, no significant Ti-O-Me (Me = Ti or Si) peaks may be found in the Ti K-edge Fourier Transformed EXAFS, either. It was observed that the average number of neighbors in the first coordination shells (NZn-O and NZn-Ni) remains fairly constant regardless of the in-situ treatment. As for the Ni/ZnAl2O4 sample, as it is shown both in Fig. 11 and Table 4, the Ni K-edge spectrum is best fitted by considering a Ni fcc phase, which is in accordance with XRD data of reduced/passivated sample (Fig. 2). From the Zn K-edge viewpoint, an inverse spinel ZnAl2O4 phase was used for fitting. The scattering paths considered in those fits were then Ni–Ni first coordination shell (dNi-Ni =2.489Å) and Zn-O and Zn-O-Al (dZn-O: 1.9522Å; dZn-O-Al: 3.3520Å) for Ni fcc and cubic ZnAl2O4, respectively. The average coordination number of Ni (NNi-Ni) did not appreciably change, being around 8±1 over the different treatments. This indicates that the Ni particle size remained approximately constant regardless of the treatment used. As far as the Zn edge is concerned, the presence of a bulky ZnAl2O4 phase is observed, unlike Ni/ZnO-Al2O3, which exhibited a NiZn intermetallic phase with non-uniform composition, as well as a rather disordered oxidic phase. Therefore, the average coordination number of Ni for both catalysts does not change significantly during the SR of ethanol reaction, which suggests that Ni particle sintering is not responsible for the deactivation observed for Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalyst. 3.5 General discussion From the above discussed results, a general picture on the evolution of phase composition of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst over the different working conditions may be drawn, as depicted in Fig. 12 . The Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 calcined catalyst precursor, comprised mainly of NiO/ZnO crystalline phases dispersed over a rather amorphous Al2O3 matrix, is transformed into a metallic phase over a ZnAl2O4 support. The composition of the metallic phase in the reduced catalyst is dependent on the Zn content in the catalyst, being that an excess of Zn (Zn:Al atomic ratio of 2:1) gives rise to a mixture of NixZny based intermetallic phase with a rather small amount of pure Ni in it. Additionally a highly dispersed ZnO phase can be seen. On the other hand, when the Zn content in the catalyst is just enough to form the ZnAl2O4 inverse spinel phase, the reduced catalyst is comprised of only Ni°/ZnAl2O4. As far as the NiZn intermetallic phase is concerned, it contains a Ni-rich phase, suggested in the present work to be a cubic Ni4Zn, associated with a Zn-richer metallic phase, suggested to be present as tetragonal NiZn. In that case, it is assumed that, during activation under H2 flow at 1023K, Zn2+ is reduced to Zn° in a process possibly aided by Ni° promoted H2 spillover. The fact that mainly two Ni-Zn intermetallic phases were observed suggests that they may occur in separate particles. Therefore, these results revealed that NiZn bimetallic particles were formed with different compositions. After 4h of flowing ethanol/H2O mixture at 773K, any detectable modification is not observed in the phase composition of the catalyst, other than an increase in the participation of a Zn-O scattering path, suggesting that at most a small part of the Zn is oxidized back to Zn2+. The formation of NiZn alloy significantly influenced the stability of the catalyst. Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst remained quite stable during SR of ethanol at 773K, which was likely due to the inhibition of carbon formation as revealed by SEM and TG analyses. However, a significant carbon deposition was observed over Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts. Therefore, the dilution effect of the large ensembles of Ni metal atoms contributed to suppressing the formation of carbon deposits, thus improving catalyst stability. In addition, the NiZn phase was quite stable and it was not destroyed during the reaction. For the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, only metallic Ni particles were found after reduction. Then, carbon filaments were formed during the reaction, leading to catalyst deactivation. in situ EXAFS did not detected significant metallic Ni sintering on Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts for SR of ethanol at 773K. However, the oxidation of metallic Ni particles was observed for SR of ethanol at low temperature (673K) and it might contribute for catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusions Two differently prepared ZnO/Al2O3 supported Ni catalysts were tested for the SR of ethanol: (i) one containing a high enough amount of Zn to form a ZnAl2O4 phase after calcination (Ni/ZnAl2O4), (ii) the other one with an excess of Zn (Ni/ZnO-Al2O4). XRD and EXAFS of the reduced Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalyst revealed only the presence of metallic Ni particles whereas a NiZn alloy with mixed compositions (NiZn and Ni4Zn) was observed for Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst. For Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, many different reactions occur simultaneously with the SR reaction at 773K such as ethanol decomposition, ethanol dehydrogenation and ethanol dehydration. On the other hand, Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst was highly selective to SR of ethanol. Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts significantly deactivated whereas Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst remained quite stable during SR of ethanol at 773K. The stability of the catalysts strongly depended on the type of Ni species formed after reduction. SEM and TG analyses revealed a significant carbon deposition over Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, which contained mainly metallic Ni particles. Carbon accumulates on the surface of Ni particles and a Ni carbide phase is formed, which is the precursor of carbon filament. However, the formation of NiZn alloy inhibited the deposition of carbon. The dilution effect of the large ensembles of Ni metal atoms contributed to suppressing the formation of carbon deposits, thus improving catalyst stability. in situ EXAFS ruled out the sintering of Ni particles during SR of ethanol at 773K. However, the oxidation of metallic Ni particles by water from the feed could play an important role on the deactivation of Ni/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst during SR of ethanol at low temperature (673K). The NiO particles formed promotes the ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde. Only a fraction of these NiO particles are reduced back over TOS. coredata.dc:description: A detailed investigation of the effect of Zn on the performance of supported Ni-based catalysts for steam reforming of ethanol is presented in this paper. A Ni/Al2O3 and two ZnO/Al2O3 supported Ni catalysts with different Zn/Al ratio were prepared. For the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZnAl2O4 (Zn/Al=0.5) catalysts, only metallic Ni particles were identified after reduction. Under ethanol steam reforming conditions, carbon filaments were formed during the reaction, which led to deactivation of the catalyst. It was shown that Zn present in excess (Ni/ZnO-Al2O3) may form an alloy with compositions ranging from Zn-rich tetragonal NiZn and Ni-rich cubic Ni4Zn. The formation of NiZn alloy with different compositions plays a key role in catalyst performance, improving resistance to coke formation and its stability.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Zn addition on the performance of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst for steam reforming of ethanol
